text:
1-5 Sixth Ave., (Now known as Nos. 301-305) at, adjoining and north of the N.W. corner of Carmine Street. No. 1 Sixth Ave., is a 3-story frame house.

About 1914.

James Suydam.
title: Manhattan : 6th Avenue - Carmine Street.

text:
South end of Sixth Avenue at Carmine Street before its extension to Church Street.

April, 1925.

Brown Brothers, Photographer.
title: Manhattan : 6th Avenue - Carmine Street.

text:
(1)
South end of Sixth Avenue, at Carmine Street.
Sixth Avenue has now been extended to Church Street.  July 31, 1926.
P.L. Sperr,Photographer.

(2)
Foot of Sixth Avenue, west side,. At this date,
Sixth Avenue's southern extremity was at Carmine
Street.
It has now been extended to Church Street.  October 11, 1928.
P.L. Sperr,Photographer.

(3)
Across Sixth Avenue wreckage from Carmine Street.
May 12, 1927.
P.L. Sperr,Photographer.

title: Manhattan : 6th Avenue - Carmine Street.

text:
Sixth Avenue Extension, south from Minetta Lane. The clearing in the immediate foreground is the site of 25 and 27 Minetta Lane and of 2-14 Carmine Street, which have been demolished. A truck is driving southeast on Bleecker Street and is passing the former north corner of Downing Street. The billboards in the distance are on the west side of Congress Street, at the S.W. corner of Houston Street.

October 11, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
Sixth Avenue, West side from Minetta Street.

October 19th, 1940

P.L.Sperr,
title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue South Extension - Minetta Lane. Left: Sixth Avenue Extension, south from Minetta Lane. The clearing in the immediate foreground is the site of 25 and 27 Minetta Lane and of 2-14 Carmine Street, which have been demolished. A truck is driving southeast on Bleecker Street and is passing the former north corner of Downing Street. The billboards in the distance are on the west side of Congress Street, at the south west corner of Houston Street, October 11, 1928. Right: Sixth Avenue, west side, from Minetta Street, October 10, 1940.

text:
(1)
New Nos. 305-303-301 Sixth Avenue (right) and 5, 7-13, 15 Carmine Street (left), west side, opposite the western end of Minetta Lane. This picture was taken during the construction of the City subway and the extension of Sixth Avenue south to Church and Franklin Streets.
October 11, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
305-303, 301 (formerly 5,3, 1) Sixth Avenue and 5, 7-9 Carmine Street, four years later, emphasising the corner house, 5 Carmine Street -- 301 Sixth Avenue, an old frame house with a brick front.

1932.

The J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.

title: Manhattan : 6th Avenue - Carmine Street.

text:
(1)
Carmine Street, north side, west from Sixth Avenue and Minetta Lane, not including No. 5 Carmine Street, the first house. Taken during the construction of the new city subway and the extension of Sixth Avenue south to Franklin Street, this view shows the cleared S.E. corner of Carmine and Bleecker Streets, and the new church of Our Lady of Pompeii on the N.W. corner, completed early in 1927 to replace the old church.
October 11, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
Carmine Street, north side, west from and including Sixth Avenue and Minetta Lane. The first Carmine Street house is No. 5, the Carmine Street side of the brick-covered frame 301 (old No. 1) Sixth Avenue.
March 15, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same as No. 1, as viewed northward from Minetta Street and across Sixth Ave. South. The apartment house on the left is at the S.W. corner of Bleecker and Carmine Streets; upon the first it bears No. 228-232 and the latter No. 22.
September 18, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Sixth Ave. (Extension), east side, north from Minetta Street, showing clearance from Minetta Street to Minetta Lane. Also seen is the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line on West 3rd Street, making a sharp bend, to continue northward on Sixth Ave.

May 29, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, including the west side of Sixth Ave., showing a playground on the former clearance.

October 29, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

text:
Minetta Street, nos. 2,4,6, Manhattan

Federal Art Project
"Changing New York"
Berenice Abbott, photographer

[Note: negative at Museum of the City of New York]
Code I A-3
Nov. 21, 1935

p.106, Changing New York

2-4-6 Minetta Street, west side, between Sixth Avenue and Minetta Lane, built between 1800 and 1807, probably the homes of artisans excluded from the then fashionable Varick Street. Occupied by ragpickers in early 1900s. Restored in 1913. Nos. 2 and 6 were remodelled in 1924. Demolished in 1936.

Sixth Ave., north from Minetta Street (right) and showing empty lots lining the east side of same. These were left when this southern extension of the Ave. was projected. The Sixth Ave. Elevated is seen making an eastward turn on West 3rd Street. In the distance appears the Empire State Building. This set of 3 views shows details of the same area.

September 18, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - Minetta Street. Sixth Avenue, north from Minetta Street (right) and showing empty lots lining the east side of same. These were left when this southern extension of the Avenue was projected. The Sixth Avenue Elevated is seen making an eastward turn on West 3rd Street. In the distance appears the Empire State Building. This set of 3 views shows details of the same area.

text:
1. Sixth Ave., east side, north from Minetta Street (right) to Minetta Lane and showing the remains of that block which contained Minetta Place in its center. Also shown is a view eastward on Minetta Street, showing larger structures lining the south side of same, east from Sixth Ave.

September 18, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

2. 6th Ave., Minetta Lane to Minetta St.
Minetta apts.
May 14, 1941

P.L. Sperr
title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - Minetta Street to Minetta Lane. Bottom: Sixth Avenue, Minetta Lane to Minetta Street. Minetta Apartments, May 14, 1941.

text:
Sixth Ave., east side, north from Minetta Street, showing grassy plots upon which were buildings prior to the extension of Sixth Ave., from Minetta Lane south to Church Street. The elongated 3-story structure on the right, that apparently faces Sixth Ave. is No. 2 Minetta Lane. Minetta Place, an enclosed Court in the center of this block formerly was in the foreground; the northern extremity of which is shown enclosed by a fence in views 2 and 3.

September 18, 1937:

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - Minetta Street. Minetta Place, an enclosed Court in the center of this block formerly was in the foreground; the northern extremity of which is shown enclosed by a fence in views 2 (middle) and 3 (right).

text:
Sixth Avenue, east side, between Minetta Street and Minetta Lane, showing in the open foreground area the site of the garden court, Minetta Place. Extension of the Avenue and related demolition caused this Greenwich Village feature of yore to disappear. Shortly two modern apartment houses will rise here. One to the right and one to the left of the dwellings, the rears of which are in the center. Incidently, these will remain, facing as they do, on Minetta Street. The tenement at the right is on the opposite side of this street.

About 1939

Alexander Alland, photo

Minetta Lane, east from 6th Avenue to MacDougal Street. At the right is a clearance across which appear the rears of buildings at the S. W. corner of Minetta Lane and Street. These are to be removed for a new 6-story apartment house according to the N. Y. Times of December 16, 1939.

April 13, 1940

P. L. Sperr
title: Manhattan: Minetta Lane - 6th Avenue: Minetta Lane, east from Sixth Avenue to MacDougal Street. At the right is a clearance across which appear the rears of buildings at the south west corner of Minetta Lane and Street. These are to be removed for a new 6-story apartment house according to the New York Times of December 16, 1939.
6th Avenue at Minetta Street, to , Manhattan
